thread.title: Police say charges dropped against TCU's Tuaua, Petties-Wilson
thread.title_full: Police say charges dropped against TCU's Tuaua, Petties-Wilson | Dallas Morning News

author: Chuck Carlton
title: Police say charges dropped against TCU's Tuaua, Petties-Wilson
text:
The Case of the Stolen Keystone Light is officially closed.
The victim has decided to not felony theft charges against TCU defensive end Mike Tuaua and wide receiver Andre Petties-Wilson, Fort Worth police said Friday.
The two were arrested last week for a Sept. 4 incident in which the two allegedly struck a TCU student outside a party and then left with a case of beer.
Tuaua and Petties-Wilson returned to practice earlier this week, although coach Gary Patterson didn't say if either would be available to play Saturday against Texas.
"As an ambassador for this university, I'm sad for all parties, not just my guys, that the incident happened," Patterson told reporters on Wednesday. "They've had a three-game suspension. I'm saddened that the whole situation went down. Hopefully, my guys learn from it."
Tuaua, a senior from California, should help a defense that has been ravaged by injuries. Last season, he recorded five sacks and 30 total tackles, including 8.5 for losses.
Patterson had strongly backed Tuaua, a captain who he called the "most-liked kid" on the team.
"In this kid's case, Mike Tuaua, we'll find out what the facts are," Patterson said Sept. 22. "It'll all come out. I just hope when they all come out, you report it just as strongly as what you've done here because it's not even close to what happened south of here."
The reference to the sexual assault conviction of Baylor football player Sam Ukwuachu, a transfer from Boise State, drew national attention.
BREAKING: Robbery charges dropped against two TCU football players after victim said he doesn't want to prosecute, police say
— ScottGordonNBC5 (@ScottGordonNBC5) October 2, 2015
Mother of TCU victim: "It's his senior year of college. He's just had enough. It's his decision" to drop case against 2 football players.
— ScottGordonNBC5 (@ScottGordonNBC5) October 2, 2015 On Twitter:
